titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the George Gissing Collection
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 1, 2019 at 04:02
profiledesc.descrules: translation missing: en.enumerations.resource_finding_aid_description_rules.beinecke manuscript unit archival processing manual

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Contains letters from George Gissing to various people, including Eduard Bertz, Edward Clodd, Algernon Gissing, Ellen Gissing, Catherine Gissing, Margaret Bedford Gissing, Thomas Waller Gissing, and Walter L. Gissing; third party letters, including those between Gabrielle Fleury and Eduard Bertz; manuscripts and notes of writings by Gissing and others; agreements between Gissing and publishers; certificates that Gissing earned in school; a few photographs of Gissing; and material collected by Percival M. Stone about Gissing's time in Waltham, Mass.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ongoing collection of documents acquired by gift and purchase from various sources. Source information is recorded on the folders. Many items in this collection were the gift of George Matthew Adams in memory of Harriet Breese Adams. Two cases with his mark have been retained as samples (Box 6, folder 105a, and Box 7, folder 148a). For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The George Gissing Collection is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: George Gissing Collection. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Box 9: Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This finding aid is updated periodically to account for new materials that have been added to the collection. The date of the most recent update is noted on the title page. For information on material that may have been acquired for the collection since the last update, please consult the Public Service Desk.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This finding aid encompasses accessions of single manuscripts and small groups of manuscripts and other papers, by or pertaining to George Gissing, acquired by the library from a variety of sources. Materials incorporated into the collection prior to January 1997 have been organized into three series, Correspondence, Writings, and Other. Materials added to the collection since that time are located in Series IV, Additions since January 1997, listed in the order in which they were added.

scopecontent.p: Autograph manuscript diagrams, showing the receipts from individual publications during each year.

did.unittitle: Caricatures and a sketch by Gissing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In ink and in pencil. Two of the caricatures are accompanied by verses with the titles, "W---m G---g's life indoors and out" and are signed "G.R.G", [Lindow Grove, Alderley Edge, Cheshire?]. Gissing's two brothers, William and Algernon, are the subjects of two of the caricatures; Gissing is himself the subject of the third. The sketch is a copy from DorÃ©'s Don Quixote.

did.unittitle: Portfolio for caricatures and a sketch by Gissing, with mark of George Matthew Adams

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manuscript quotations entered by the Gissing family and friends. Many leaves blank. One pen and ink sketch, one water color drawing. Bound in cardboard with chromolithograph on cover.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph manuscript notes. Also on on Albrecht DÃ¼rer's engraving, followed by six pencil sketches. Colored bookplate, unattached of Harry Bache Smith.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Removed from: Love's Labour's Lost by William Shakespeare (London, [1864]).

did.unittitle: Notebook containing autograph manuscript notes about his novels

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Publisher, date, numbers of copies sold, and royalties, from The Unclassed (1884) to The Private Papers of Henry Ryecrofs (1902). Black paper covers, with calendars for 1889 and 1899 inside front cover.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph manuscript, in a brown leather-covered notebook, containing some quotations and suggestions for plots. A brief itinerary is noted on the inside front cover on p. [1].

did.unittitle: "Poetry Copied by Gissing," [Lindow Grove School, Alderly Edge, Cheshire?]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Note on p. [1]: "I suppose about the year 1873. G.R.G. 1879." Contents include Gray's "Elegy" and Shelley's "To a Skylark." Laid in is: p. 379-80 of "Temple Bar," vol. 69, no. 276, Nov. 1883. Gissing's "Song" is on p. 379.

did.unittitle: "Reminiscences of My Father, Jotted Down from Time to Time as They Chance to Occur to Me"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph manuscript.

did.unittitle: Seven photographs of places of interest in Gissing's life

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 1) Eversley, Worple Road, Epsom, England. 2) 62 Milton Street, London, N.W., England. 3) 7K Cornwall Residences, Regents Park, London. 4) George Gissing's birthplace. 5) Ciboure, Basses, Pyrenees, France, George Gissing's grave. 6) Plaque in the entrance to the Chemist's shop, birthplace of Gissing. 7) Lindow Grove School, Alderley Edge, Cheshire, England.

did.unittitle: Materials collected by Percival M. Stone about Gissing's residence in Waltham, Mass.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes letters (two by Vincent Starrett), articles, clippings, photographs, and commencement program relating to Gissing's residence in Waltham, Mass., where he was a teacher of English in the Waltham High School in 1876-1877.

did.unittitle: ALS to Joseph Anderson, Eversley, Epson

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With: envelope and four clippings.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.
